Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Energy Efficient and Reliable Motion Mechanism for Ocean Wave Energy Harvesting

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The potential of wave energy source in the US is estimated to be 64% of the total electricity generated in 2010. Over 53% of the US population lives within 50 miles of the coasts, so ocean waves offer ready opportunity to provide electricity for the population without long-distance electricity transmission. The power takeoff - the machinery to convert the mechanical energy into electricity - is considered as the single most important element in wave energy technology, and underlies many of the failures of ocean wave energy systems to date. Revolutionary power takeoff is urgently needed in order to realize the high electricity potential from the untapped ocean waves. The objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project is to experimentally and theoretically investigate the design, modeling and control of an innovative ocean power takeoff mechanism to solve the most fundamental challenge in wave energy harvesting. The power takeoff offers much higher energy conversion efficiency, enhanced reliability, and unmatched compactness, and completely eliminates hydraulic components for potential environmental pollution. It can be integrated into the point absorbers, wave attenuators, wave terminators, or other type of wave energy converter whenever oscillatory wave motion is involved. Therefore, the success of this research will help establishing the leadership role of the US in the area of ocean wave energy. This project is expected to pave a sustainable energy pathway of harvesting vast but untapped ocean wave sources to meet the increasingly urgent national demand for energy and energy security.

Multidisciplinary research on energy manufacturing, marine hydrodynamics, mechatronics design, multi-physics modeling, control, and in-field study will be conduct in this project. The state-of-the-art ocean wave energy technology either uses direct-drive power takeoffs with linear electromagnetic generator or indirect-drive power takeoffs using intermediate fluid. The direct drives are simple and reliable but require heavy and bulk permanent magnets; the indirect drives are more compact but suffer from serious shortcomings on the complexity, reliability, and efficiency. The research team will create and investigate a "mechanical motion rectifier" based power takeoff to uniquely convert the irregular oscillatory wave motion into regular unidirectional rotation of the generator, having the advantages of direct and indirect drives. The research team will also systematically study the vibration energy harvesting synthesis from new perspective of modern electrical engineering including diodes and transistors. Multi-body dynamic motion magnification will also be investigated to significantly enhance the power extraction capacity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ocean wave energy potential in the US is 64% of the total electricity generated from all sources. Over 53% of the US population lives within 50 miles of a coast, so ocean waves offer exceptional opportunity. The recorded interest in energy harvesting from ocean waves dates back to a patent in 1799, and significant R&D efforts in Europe and Japan have recently led to important advances; however, the ocean wave energy technology is still in its infancy worldwide. One of the most important challenges is the power takeoff (PTO) mechanism, the machinery that converts kinetic energy of the waves into electricity. As Falcao pointed out in a major review in 2010, the PTO ?is possibly the single most important element in wave energy technology, and underlies many (possibly most) of the failures to date.?

The objective of this project is to experimentally and theoretically investigate an innovative power takeoff system based on the concept of mechanical motion rectifier (MMR) to solve the most fundamental challenge in ocean wave energy harvesting. In this project, the team created a rack pinion based ?mechanical motion rectifier? and demonstrated the direct conversion of the irregular oscillatory wave motions into regular unidirectional rotation of the electrical generator. We also showed that the system with MMR based power takeoff can produce more power comparing with linear damping power takeoff system. Lab test was conducted to validate the high efficiency and ocean test demonstrated the feasibility. The team also investigated the two-body wave energy converter and derived suboptimal and optimal parameter designs in closed form. We showed through analysis and wave tank tests that, by using the relative motion between the floating and submerged bodies the absorption power of the two-body system can be significantly higher than that of the single body system with the same floating buoy in both regular and irregular waves. We also discovered that the flywheel can increase the power output at higher frequency, and the reduction of viscous or drag damping can increase the power output at low frequency.  

This project has generated a lot of impacts. The PI and students won the ?Best Technical Development of a Large-Scale Energy Harvesting Device, in Energy Harvesting & Storage and IoT Applications Awards USA 2014, and the prestigious R&D100 Award in Nov 2015 by R&D Magazine, nicknamed ?Oscar of Innovation?. Many news medias reported our ocean wave energy work, such as ?Riding an Energy Wave?, a featured story on the ASME Mechanical Engineering Magazine in 2016. The PI also was selected as the sole recipient of 2015 ASME Thar Energy Design Award and 2017 ASME Leonardo Da Vinci Award. The team also won a DOE grant which would further improve the PTO reliability and efficiency over the baseline system in the NSF project. Quite a few companies inside and outside USA approached the team for the collaborations or technology transfer.

 

This project provided training opportunities for several graduate, over 10 undergraduate students and some high school students, in the multiple disciplinary areas including fluid, hydrodynamics, mechanical design, vibration, dynamics, control, and electronics. We published 3 journal papers on this project and had four more submiited in review. We also published quite a few conference papers.  Invited to give many keynote talks or seminars, the PI widely disseminated the research findings to different communities. The PI also gave showcase in the USA Science and Engineering Festival and presented the research work to over 100 K-12 students.
